� General Information
The following describes the general rules for determination of the con?guration data
Every constant NC_xxx_CONF describes whether a system is equipped with additional functionality or not.
? Sensor-Con?guration
For all sensors (NC_xxx_CONF) following possibilities are available:
0 = NO_SENSOR: sensor is not available, value never used
1 = SENSOR_ALWAYS_USED: sensor is always available and value is used
2 = SENSOR_SWITCHABLE: sensor-evaluation can be switched "on / off "during runtime by LC_switch)

CHRA, CHRA General
9.2 CHRA General
� General Information
In state of the art combustion engines, downsizing and engine ef?ciency are reached by increasing the gas
pressure before the cylinder intake.
This boost pressure is controlled via an actuator, usually a wastegate or a variable geometry turbine (VTG),
by varying the rotation velocity of the turbine. There are 2 types of actuators: the pneumatic one and the
electrical one.
Moreover, a recirculation actuator (open/close system) avoids the pumping of the turbo charger when the
throttle closes after a high load by letting compressed air out of the turbo charger
All these actuators are covered by the aggregate CHRA.
9.2.1 Electrical VTG/wastegate actuator
The electrical actuator is working with an electrical DC motor.
It is usually using a H-bridge as power stage.
It also has a position sensor allowing a closed-loop regulation of the valve.
The algorithm gets as input from the charger controller a position setpoint and realizes it autonomously.
List of contained functions
The task of the CHRA aggregate for an electrical actuator is to realize the requested actuator position de-
pendent on the engine operating states and the driver request. For this purpose the aggregate includes all
necessary functions for the closed-loop boost pressure actuator position control and the corresponding level
1 diagnosis functions.
Additionally all level 1 diagnosis functions are observed from the limp-home management of the aggregate.
Possible fault reactions are the deactivation of the power stage and the deactivation of the closed-loop, thus
operating stationary with a constant calibrated PWM value.

? CHRA - Cleaning
? CHRA - Sensor Acquisition
Inner-aggregate architecture
Besides the nominal operation (position controlling) the aggregate also features supportive functions (adap-
tion, anti-sticking, cleaning, limp home, external command and protection) that interrupt the nominal be-
haviour. Which intervention is allowed to take place is decided in the operating manager.

9.2.2 Pneumatic VTG/wastegate actuator
The pneumatic actuator is using a pneumatic valve to regulate the pressure actuating its moveable part. This
valve consists of a magnet and a spring moved according to a PWM signal and modulating the income of 2
different pressures (these can be the ambient pressure, underpressure or boost pressure).
Figure 9.2.2: Example of a pneumatic valve
The pneumatic actuator is usually using a low-side driver as power stage.

CHRA, CHRA General
It does not have any position feedback; the feedback is done over 2 different loops including the charger
controller.
The algorithm gets as input the actuation pressure setpoint as well as the 2 input pressures of the pneumatic
valve and a correction factor for the PWM value.
List of contained functions
The task of the CHRA aggregate for a pneumatic actuator is to realize the requested actuator position cor-
responding to the actuation pressure setpoint given by the charger controller. For this purpose the CHRA
aggregate includes all necessary functions for the open-loop boost pressure actuator position control and the
corresponding level 1 diagnosis function (deactivation of the power stage).
? Acquisition of pressure at pneumatic waste gate actuator (only dummy in SC1)
? Waste gate actuator pressure
? Turbocharger turbine actuator coordination
? Waste gate electrical diagnosis
? Waste gate electrical diagnosis (Appl. Inc.)
Inner-aggregate architecture
With help of the inverse wastegate valve model, the required actuation pressure is converted into a PWM value
which is applied to the power stage after addition of a correction factor coming from the charger controller
(CHRG aggregate).
The wastegate valve model transforms the PWM value back into an actuation pressure which is used by the
charger controller as a feedback. This is the inner feedback loop.
An outer feedback loop, present in the charger controller, is based on the exhaust gas pressure feedback.

The recirculation actuator is usually using a pneumatic valve.
The recirculation actuator is usually using a low-side driver as power stage.
It is an open-loop system open/close system.

CHRA, Waste gate actuator pressure
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
LC_PQ_EPC_OUT V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Switch whether PQ_EPC_OUT is calculated based on absolute (= 0) or relative pressure (= 1)
LC_PRS_WG_ACR_MAN V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Switch whether manual value for wastegate actuator pressure is used
� General Information
The wastgate actuator pressure PRS_WG_ACR can be measured or modelled. If a wastegate actuator pressure
sensor is available (LV_ENA_PRS_WG_ACR = 1), the measured value PRS_WG_ACR_MES is used, otherwise a
modelled value is used instead. The modelled or measured value can be overwritten by a manual value
C_PRS_WG_ACR_MAN.
Two electropneumatic converter (EPC) types are covered. For C_TYP_EPC_WG_ACR = 0 both supply pres-
sure and ambient pressure in?uence the wastegate actuator pressure. For C_TYP_EPC_WG_ACR = 1 only
supply pressure in?uences the wastegate actuator pressure.
The behaviour of the EPC type 0 is modelled using two different algorithms switched by LC_PQ_EPC_
OUT.
For LC_PQ_EPC_OUT = 0 IP_PQ_EPC_OUT describes the ratio between absolute pressures at the output and
at the input of the EPC:
Figure 9.4.1:
For LC_PQ_EPC_OUT = 1 IP_PQ_EPC_OUT describes the ratio between pressure differences at the output
and at the input of the EPC:
Figure 9.4.2:
To take into account the ?lling behaviour of the wastegate actuator the wastegate actuator pressure is low
pass ?ltered.

9.4.2.1.1 Wastegate actuator pressure calculation
The pressure in wastegate actuator chamber is calculated regarding the EPC type, and whether PQ_EPC_OUT
is calculated based on relative pressure (1) or absolute pressure (0).
The pressure ratio at the input and output of the electropneumatic converter are not affected by these terms.
The corrected PWM at the electropneumatic converter for WG actuator will be set to 100% when there is
not PWM at EPC or there is not air temperature correction slope, otherwise, if this conditions are not true the
correction will be a factor depending on 4 parameters:
1. PWM at EPC for WG actuation
2. Correction factor of PWM_WG due to battery voltage
3. Air temperature correction offset of wastegate PWM
4. Air temperature correction slope of wastegate PWM.

CHRA, Recirculation actuator position
9.5.2 Operate
9.5.2.1 Calculation of the recirculation actuator position
The recirculation actuator position PSN_RCL can be measured or modeled. If a recirculation actuator position
sensor is available and delivers a valid value (LV_ENA_PSN_RCL=1), the measured value PSN_RCL_MES is used,
otherwise a modeled value is used instead. A manual value ( _MAN) can overwrite both measured and model
value.
The position for the recirculation actuator will be set to C_PSN_RCL_MAN whether the manual switch for re-
circulation actuator position (LC_PSN_RCL_MAN) is active. If this is not the case, the measured recirculation
actuator position (PSN_RCL_MES) will be set while the enable ?ag for recirculation actuator position sensor is
active (LV_ENA_PSN_RCL).
If the previous conditions are not ful?lled, the PSN_RCL gets its value of 0 or 1depending on the presence of an
electrical error or limp home request.

� Function Description
If ACTION_FARM_GetPermission (NC_FID_ERR_RCL_STUCK_PSN_CLOSE) = 1
or LC_ERR_PLAUS_RCL_ACR_SUPP = 1
Then LV_LIH_RCL_STUCK_PSN_CLOSE = 0
Else LV_LIH_RCL_STUCK_PSN_CLOSE = 1
EndIf
If ACTION_FARM_GetPermission (NC_FID_ERR_RCL_STUCK_PSN_OPEN) = 1
or LC_ERR_PLAUS_RCL_ACR_SUPP = 1
Then LV_LIH_RCL_STUCK_PSN_OPEN = 0
Else LV_LIH_RCL_STUCK_PSN_OPEN = 1
EndIf
Note: The output of ACTION_FARM_GetPermission is used as return value.

� Import actions:
ACTION_INFR_SetCmdRcl(IN <CtrCmdRcl>, IN <LvCmdRcl>)
� General Information
The present speci?cation describes the simplest possible switching control of the recirculation actuator posi-
tion If the position setpoint PSN_RCL_SP is greater than a threshold C_PSN_RCL_THD_DIG_CTL then LV_CMD_
RCL_OPEN is set to 1 to completely open the actuator. Otherwise LV_CMD_RCL_OPEN is set to 0 to completely
close the actuator. An external control LV_RCL_EXT_ADJ is activated via LV_ACT_RCL_EXT_ADJ.
In the present version PWM_RCL is a dummy output to have a common output interface with more sophisti-
cated speci?cation versions which are designed to control a continuous recirculation actuator (?ap or propor-
tional valve).

9.8.2.1 PWM calculation
Subsystem CLC_PWM_WG_BAS represents the characteristic of the electropneumatic converter at reference
conditions, CLC_PWM_WG_OPL applies corrections due to temperatures and battery voltage, CLC_PWM_WG
sums up with the charge air pressure controller and coordinates with external adjustments.
9.8.2.1.1 Basic pre-control PWM at wastegate EPC
Two types of electropneumatic converters are covered: C_TYP_EPC_WG_ACR = 1 is used with EPCs, whose
output pressure depends only on the applied PWM signal, as long as supply pressure is big or small enough
.
C_TYP_EPC_WG_ACR = 0 is used with EPCs whose output pressure depends both on applied PWM signal and
input pressures. LC_PQ_EPC_OUT is used to switch between two calibration strategies for IP_PWM_WG_OPL
and IP_PRS_DIF_WG_ACR in module Wastegate actuator pressure. If LC_PQ_EPC_OUT = 0 then the ratio of
requested actuator pressure and supplied high pressure at the electropneumatic converter is used as PQ_
EPC_OUT_SP. If LC_PQ_EPC_OUT = 1 then the ratio of the difference (between requested actuator pressure and
supplied high pressure at the electropneumatic converter) and the difference between supplied high and low
pressure at the electropneumatic converter is used as PQ_EPC_OUT_SP.

CHRA, Recirculation actuator diagnosis
The RCL actuator is driven by the ECU via an output driver. The failure detection is done by ECU hardware.
The purpose of the diagnosis is to detect electrical faults as de?ned by OBD I requirements.
After activation conditions are met, the diagnosis activation is delayed for NC_PSD_DLY_EL_RCL_ACR execu-
tions, to avoid the usage of wrong infrastructure information.
The data LV_END_DIAG_EL_RCL_ACR and LV_CDN_DIAG_EL_RCL_ACR are not present in output data, since
they are not used by other functions. Nevertheless; they are provided in error management and always
visible.
The error management variables are initialized according to ?lter type.

CHRA, Recirculation actuator diagnosis (Appl. Inc.)
9.10 Recirculation actuator diagnosis (Appl. Inc.)
� Data De?nition
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
LV_INH_DIAG_EL_RCL_ACR O/V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
one indicates inhibition of the electrical RCL actuator Diagnosis
� Input Data
LC_TCHA_CONF
{p. 2379}
LV_ES
{p. 7530}
� Calibration Data
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
LC_INH_DIAG_EL_RCL_ACR V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
If set to 1 then the RCL actuator Electrical diagnosis is inhibited
� Con?guration Data
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
NC_FID_ERR_EL_RCL_ACR - 0... FFFFH 0... 65535 1 -
Run the diagnostics to detect RCL actuator electrical failure
� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
� General Information
The ?ag LV_INH_DIAG_x_RCL allows to deactivate the corresponding RCL diagnostic.
The diagnosis is inhibited if LC_INH_DIAG_EL_RCL_ACR is set to 1 or there is no permission to run the diag-
nostics (usually due to other errors).
The Formula section must be updated by the Project. The Calibration data list must be completed.
The project can add additional conditions if desired.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: At Reset and Transition LV_ES = 0 to 1:
LV_INH_DIAG_EL_RCL_ACR = 0
Activation: LC_TCHA_CONF = 1
Deactivation: LC_TCHA_CONF = 0

CHRA, Recirculation actuator diagnosis (Appl. Inc.)
Recurrence: 10 ms
� Function Description
If NOT(ACTION_FARM_GetPermission (NC_FID_ERR_EL_RCL_ACR))
Or LC_INH_DIAG_EL_RCL_ACR = 1
Then LV_INH_DIAG_EL_RCL_ACR = 1
Else LV_INH_DIAG_EL_RCL_ACR = 0
Endif
Note: The output of ACTION_FARM_GetPermission is used as return value.

ACTION_CHRA_ResetDiagWgOc ACTION_CHRA_GetSdrWgOc
� General Information
The Waste Gate (WG) is driven by the ECU via an output driver. The failure detection is done by ECU hardware.
The purpose of the diagnosis is to detect electrical faults as de?ned by OBD I requirements.
After activation conditions are met, the diagnosis activation is delayed for NC_PSD_DLY_WG executions, to
avoid the usage of wrong infrastructure information.
The data LV_END_DIAG_WG and LV_CDN_DIAG_WG are not present in output data, since they are not used by
other functions. Nevertheless; they are provided in error management and always visible.
The error management variables are initialized according to ?lter type.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, IGKON
Activation: LC_TCHA_CONF
Deactivation: !LC_TCHA_CONF
Recurrence: 100MS

ACTION_CHRA_ResetDiagBpaTolWarn ACTION_CHRA_GetSdrBpaAdTolWarn
� General Information
This function makes an adaptation of the position sensor by storing the sensor values at the end position of
the actuator for reference as top and bottom limit values. These values are stored in non volatile memory.
The adaptation is temperature dependant, a separate limit value is stored for top and bottom. The nominal
temperature adaptation value is saved as absolute value (temperature range 1), the others as values relative
to the nominal one (corrected with the voltage difference value). In this way, the whole adaptation curve will
shift up or down when the nominal value is learnt. When one of the others is learnt, the shape of the curve
File: MCA0Q701.00C
2046Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE

CHRA, CHRA adaptation and diagnosis
will change. The purpose is avoid sudden large changes of the non-nominal adaptation values in case they
cannot be learnt regularly.
Before saving, the adaptation values are diagnosed that they are not outside of an absolute range or have
changed too much since their last adaptation. Actuator wear warning is also available in order to detect an
actuator that is used up (voltage values above used up threshold).
The resulting top and bottom limit for the present temperature is ?nally used to calculate the current sensor
characteristic between bottom and top limit. A choice is possible to used constant bottom or top limits or
offsets instead.
The adaptation values should be written in a part of the EEPROM which is not erased during a SW up-
date.(i.e. all the NVMY data should be written in ?xed channel of the EEPROM in SW)

Deactivation: LC_BPA_CTL_ENA==0

9.13.2.3.1 CHRA_ADPDGBPA
To save CPU load, only the request is always calculated in a fast recurrence.

Since the interpolation depends
on a slowly changing temperature, it is suf?cient to calculate this in a slow recurrence.
Those parts which are needed when the adaptation is running (passively or actively), are only calculated
conditionally.

9.13.2.3.1.2.1 Adaptation request
By choice, an active commanded adaptation can be requested at end of production line, via after-sales or
when no successful adaption has taken place so far.
The active adaptation can also be commanded during power latch, and it can be selected that power latch
state does not occur after wake-up (LC_BPA_AD_PWL_ACT = 0).

9.13.2.3.1.2.4 Adaptation Diagnosis
In case an active or passive (if selected: LC_BPA_AD_PAS_DIAG = 1) adaptation for BOL or TOL is ended suc-
cessfully, the ?ag for successful adaptation in the present driving cycle is set. The ?ag a successful adaptation
in the present driving cycle is reset in case a BOL / TOL adaptation error occurs (the error is set as soon as the
symptom is detected, without any anti-bounce ?ltering) and the errors are activated (by calibration) to reset
the successful adaptation in the present driving cycle ?ag.
Once a ?rst adaptation has been performed successfully the ?ag for adaptation successful in the ?rst driving
cycle is set. This ?ag should only be reset by the tester tool (in case of component change) or in case of non
volatile memory loss.
If a request for adaptation is commanded for basic settings, the ?ags for adaptation successful in the ?rst and
present driving cycle are reset.

9.13.2.3.1.2.5.1 BOL Adaptation Change limitation
The step voltage for bottom limit adaptation is calculated depending on LV_BPA_AD_SUC_DC_FIRST.
If a ?rst adaptation is done then the C_VP_BPA_AD_REL_FIRST is used (a bigger difference value), if not
then C_VP_BPA_AD_REL with a smaller voltage difference value is considered.
The step voltage for bottom limit adaptation is also calculated depending on the reference exhaust tempera-
ture, that is why VP_BPA_AD_DIF correction is subtracted from the ?ltered voltage value.

9.13.2.3.1.2.7 BOL maximum / TOL minimum adaptation values over boost pressure actuator lifetime
The bottom limit maximum / top limit minimum adaptation values over actuator component lifetime are calcu-
lated and stored in the non-volatile memory ?xed channel as VP_BPA_AD_BOL_MAX / VP_BPA_AD_TOL_MIN.
If the current adaptation values VP_BPA_AD_BOL / VP_BPA_AD_TOL are detected as lower / higher than the
maximum / minimum adaptation value over boost pressure actuator lifetime - / + lower respectively upper
tolerance threshold, it means the component has been replaced; therefore, the bottom limit maximum / top
limit minimum adaptation values over component life time are reset to the initial substitute values for the
respective end limit of the boost pressure actuator feedback sensor.

9.13.2.4 First adaptation commanded by tester result
When the ?rst adaptation triggered by the EOL tester is ended ?ag LV_END_DIAG_EOL_TEST_BPA is set.
In case this adaptation was not successful, ?ag LV_ERR_EOL_TEST_BPA is set.
If the adaptation is triggered for more than one actuator, the information that the adaptation requested by
the
tester tool is ended will be true when the adaptation and diagnosis for all actuators is ended. The error ?ag
will be set in case the ?rst adaptation for either one of the actuators is not successful.

� General Information
This module handles the limp home management for the boost pressure actuator.
In case of a power stage error the power stage is shut off.
In case of actuator or sensor errors a static PWM is requested.

Initialisation: RST
Activation: LC_BPA_CTL_ENA==1
Deactivation: LC_BPA_CTL_ENA==0
Recurrence: 10MS

9.15 CHRA fault operation manager (Appl. Inc.)
� Data De?nition
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
LV_LIH_BPA_ACR [NC_NR_BPA] O/V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Boost pressure actuator limp home request in case of sensor or actuator failure
LV_LIH_BPA_DR [NC_NR_BPA] O/V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Boost pressure actuator driver limp home request in case of power stage failure
� Input Data
LC_BPA_CTL_ENA
{p. 2270}
NC_NR_BPA
{p. 1939}
� Con?guration Data
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
NC_FID_ERR_BPA_ACR [NC_NR_BPA] - 0... FFFFH 0... 65535 1 -
Run the boost pressure actuator sensor and actuator diagnostics
NC_FID_ERR_BPA_DR [NC_NR_BPA] - 0... FFFFH 0... 65535 1 -
Run the boost pressure actuator power stage diagnostics
� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
� General Information
The boost pressure actuator sensor and power stage diagnosis are inhibited if there is no permission to run
the diagnostics.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: At reset:
For i=0 to NC_NR_BPA-1
LV_LIH_BPA_ACR[i] = 0
LV_LIH_BPA_DR[i] = 0
EndFor
Activation: LC_BPA_CTL_ENA = 1
Deactivation: LC_BPA_CTL_ENA = 0
Recurrence: 10 ms
� Function Description

CHRA, CHRA fault operation manager (Appl. Inc.)
For i=0 to NC_NR_BPA - 1
If ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(NC_FID_ERR_BPA_ACR[i]) = 1
Then LV_LIH_BPA_ACR[i] = 0
Else LV_LIH_BPA_ACR[i] = 1
EndIf
If ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(NC_FID_ERR_BPA_DR[i]) = 1
Then LV_LIH_BPA_DR[i] = 0
Else LV_LIH_BPA_DR[i] = 1
EndIf
EndFor
Note: The output of ACTION_FARM_GetPermission is used as return value.

� General Information
This diagnosis function is used to monitor the power stage of the boost pressure actuator.
The diagnostic is con?gurated in SPI mode and is able to detect short circuit (to power or ground), open circuit
and over heat.

9.16.2.1.1.1.3 Short circuit diagnosis
A short circuit could only be detected at the switches from the H-bridge which are open. The conditions for
the different short cuts have to be calculated depending of the power stage feedback.

CHRA, CHRA sensor diagnosis
� General Information
This diagnosis function is used to monitor the admissible input voltage range of the boost pressure actuator
position sensor system. The diagnostic is able to detect short circuit to battery, open circuit and short circuit
to ground for the position sensor input according to the pull resistor at the input of the AD converter.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, IGKON
Activation: LC_BPA_CTL_ENA==1
Deactivation: LC_BPA_CTL_ENA==0
Recurrence: 10MS

� General Information
The task of this diagnosis is to detect an boost pressure actuator error or a jammed actuator. The diagnostic
observes the control deviation of the closed loop position control system dependent on the gradient of the
actuator position setpoint.
Additionally the position controller output is monitored by this diagnostic function. If the moving mean value
of PWM_BPA exceeds a de?ned threshold than an error will be indicated. The calculation of the moving mean
value is done by a low pass ?lter ?rst order.
The controller deviation and the PWM output control value can be monitored both in during normal engine
operation and during catalyst heating, for cold start emission reduction purpose.
The following error symptoms can be distinguished:
PWM error of the closed loop position control system in normal operation or / and catalyst heating
System deviation outside the admissible range in normal operation or / and catalyst heating.

9.18.2.1.1.1 Evaluation of diagnostic condition
The section calculates the diagnostic condition of the diagnosis. The condition diagnosis is only set with active
closed-loop actuator position control.
The actuator diagnosis during catalyst heating is only released if the position setpoint for boost pressure
actuator during catalyst heating is currently active: LV_POSN_SP_BPA_CH is set.
Separate time after start and temperature thresholds are used for activating the actuator diagnosis during
catalyst heating.
The controller deviation diagnosis during normal operation will be active also during catalyst heating.
The controller deviation diagnosis during catalyst heating will be active only if LC_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH_DIAG_
ENA is set and the difference between the position setpoint during normal operation and the position setpoint
during catalyst heating is above calibrated threshold C_POSN_SP_BPA_RGL_CH_DIF_THD.
It is possible to switch between the controller PWM output outside admissible range diagnosis in normal
operation or during catalyst heating (if the position setpoint during catalyst heating currently active) by setting
calibration switch LC_PWM_BPA_CH_DIAG_ENA. If this switch is not set, PWM output outside admissible range
diagnosis during catalyst heating is not active and PWM output outside admissible range diagnosis in normal
operation will be active.

The setpoint gradient is used for calculating the control deviation threshold value used for position deviation

Figure 9.18.21:
9.18.2.1.1.3.1.1.1.2 Controller deviation error detection
The error detection algorithm checks the control deviation against the admissible control deviation thresh-
old. If the deviation exceeds the admissible threshold an error will be indicated.
If LC_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_DC_HEAL calibration switch is set and a control deviation error is present, this error can
only be healed in the current or next driving cycle if actuator movement us detected. Movement is indicated
by the current voltage value which should be lower / higher than the voltage value that was stored at the time
that the error was ?rst detected - / + an offset; the offset subtraction / addition and actual voltage comparison
direction depend on the sign of the position deviation, showing that the actuator was stuck towards closed
/ open position when the position deviation error was detected.

9.18.2.1.1.3.1.1.2 Control deviation symptom de-bouncing condition
The control deviation symptom is de-bounced when the position deviation symptom ?ltering is activated:
- when either the position deviation value is higher than the maximum threshold or when actuator movement
is detected, if LC_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_DC_HEAL calibration switch is set or control deviation error is present;
- always, if LC_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_DC_HEAL calibration switch is not set or no control deviation error is present.

Figure 9.18.41:
9.18.2.1.1.3.3.1.1.2 Control deviation during catalyst heating error detection
The error detection algorithm checks the control deviation during catalyst heating against the admissible
threshold. If the control deviation during catalyst heating exceeds the corresponding admissible threshold an
error will be indicated.
If LC_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH_DC_HEAL calibration switch is set and a control deviation error during catalyst heat-
ing is present, this error can only be healed in the current or next driving cycle if actuator movement is de-
tected. Movement is indicated by the current voltage value which is lower / higher than the voltage value that
was stored at the time that the error was ?rst detected - / + an offset for catalyst heating operation; the offset
subtraction / addition and actual voltage comparison direction depend on the sign of the position deviation,

active if LC_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH_DC_HEAL calibration switch is not set or no control deviation error during
catalyst heating is present; in the other cases, symptom ?ltering is only activated when the position devia-
tion during catalyst heating is detected or when actuator movement during catalyst heating is detected and
symptom should be de-bounced.

Figure 9.18.42:
9.18.2.1.1.3.3.1.2 Control deviation during catalyst heating symptom de-bouncing condition
The control deviation during catalyst heating symptom is de-bounced when the position deviation during
catalyst heating symptom ?ltering is activated:
- when either the position deviation value during catalyst heating is higher than the maximum threshold or
when actuator movement is detected, if LC_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH_DC_HEAL calibration switch is set or control
deviation error is present;
- always, if LC_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH_DC_HEAL calibration switch is not set or no control deviation error during
catalyst heating is present.

9.19.1 Boost pressure actuator control diagnosis inhibition
� General Information
The boost pressure actuator control diagnosis (position deviation above maximum limit POSN_DIF_BPA_H, com-
mand value too high PWM_BPA_H or too low PWM_BPA_L) is inhibited if there is no permission to run these
diagnostics.

Initialisation: At RST, IGKON:
For i=0 to NC_NR_BPA-1
LV_INH_BPA_ACR[i] = 0
EndFor

9.19.2 Boost pressure actuator control rate based monitoring
� General Information
With this module the interface between the XX monitor and the Rate-Based Monitoring statistics is de?ned
with STATE_RBM_XX data.
Within STATE_RBM_XX, three different information are de?ned:
? Conditions for monitoring are met long enough to detect malfunction (bit 0)
? (no intrusive operation, no short trip)
? Monitor disabled because of system malfunction (bit 1)
? (depending on failure status: pending)
? Monitor individual RBM conditions encountered within this DC (bit 2)
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: At RST:
For i=0...NC_NR_BPA-1 Do
T_RBM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH[i] = 0
STATE_RBM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH[i] = 0
T_RBM_PWM_BPA_CH[i] = 0
STATE_RBM_PWM_BPA_H_CH[i] = 0
STATE_RBM_PWM_BPA_L_CH[i] = 0
EndFor
Activation: LV_FID_READY = 1
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 1 s

ing
For i=0...NC_NR_BPA-1 Do
If bit 0 of STATE_RBM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH[i] == 0
Then
If ACTION_ERRM_GetEndDiag(IN<NC_IDX_ERR_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH[i]>) == 1
Then
// Conditions for monitoring are met long enough to detect malfunction
bit 0 of STATE_RBM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH[i] = 1
ACTION_ERRM_IncRbmMonitorNumFor (NC_IDX_RBM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH[i])
EndIf
EndIf
If bit 2 of STATE_RBM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH[i] == 0
Then
If T_RBM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH[i] >= C_T_RBM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH[i]
// POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH active time more then 10 seconds
Then
// Monitor individual RBM conditions encountered within this DC (bit
2)
bit 2 of STATE_RBM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH[i] = 1
ACTION_ERRM_IncRbmMonitorDenFor (NC_IDX_RBM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH[i])
EndIf
EndIf
If LV_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH_DIAG_CDN == 1
Then
T_RBM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH[i] = T_RBM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_CH[i] + 1s
EndIf
EndFor
9.19.2.2 Boost pressure actuator duty cycle value high / low during catalyst heating rate-based
monitoring

If bit 2 of STATE_RBM_PWM_BPA_H_CH[i] == 0
Then
If T_RBM_PWM_BPA_CH[i] >= C_T_RBM_PWM_BPA_CH[i]
// PWM_BPA_H_CH active time more then 10 seconds

The short trip is activated by UDS Id 03EC sent by an external Tester.
It is used for the function check of the E-wastegate actuator after assembling with the wastegate. After the

closed again after a calibratable time is elapsed. The setpoint oft the voltage from the actuator, in open and
closed position, must be measured while this precedure.
This short trip can not be activated within the EOL-manager and can not be used within the routine acti-
vated by UDS ID 311hex (old MVB 200).
It can only be used as a single short trip while the engine is not running.

CHRA, CHRA diagnosis (gen)
9.23 CHRA diagnosis (gen)
� General Information:
This boost pressure is controlled with an actuator, usually a wastegate or a variable geometry turbine (VTG).
The task of CHRA is to realize the requested actuator position dependent on the engine operating states and
the driver request. For this purpose the aggregate includes all necessary functions for the closed-loop boost
pressure actuator position control and the corresponding level 1 diagnosis functions.
Additionally all level 1 diagnosis functions are observed from the limp-home management of the aggregate.
Possible fault reactions are the deactivation of the power stage and the deactivation of the close-loop, thus
operating stationary with a constant calibrated PWM value.
Besides the nominal operation (position controlling) the aggregate also features supportive functions (e.g.
adaption, anti-sticking, cleaning, limp home, external command and protection) that interrupt the nominal
behavior. Which intervention is allowed to take place is decided in the operating manager.
This document has the purpose to give calibration engineering aid to internal and customer calibration teams.
Thus, this document describe in detail the interconnections with other Calibration functions one has to respect
during calibration work and a detailed plan of calibration.
� Calibration Interfering Functions
The calibration of the BPA diagnostic functions is the base for the later calibration of the adaptation function
and the digital position controller.
� Calibration Flowchart:
The following ?owchart describes the sequence of the calibration:
Figure 9.23.1: Calibration sequence ?owchart
� Calibration Process:
� BPA position sensor diagnosis
? This diagnosis function is used to monitor the admissible input voltage range of the boost pressure
actuator position sensor system. The diagnostic is able to detect a too high or too low voltage of the
position sensor.

� BPA actuator diagnosis
The task of this diagnosis is to detect an boost pressure actuator error or a jammed actuator. The diagnostic
observes the control deviation of the closed loop position control system dependent on the gradient of the
actuator position setpoint.
Additionally the position controller output is monitored by this diagnostic function. If the moving mean value
of PWM_BPA exceeds a de?ned threshold than an error will be indicated. The calculation of the moving mean
value is done by a low pass ?lter ?rst order.
The controller deviation and the PWM output control value can be monitored both in during normal engine
operation and during catalyst heating, for cold start emission reduction purpose.
The following error symptoms can be distinguished:
PWM error of the closed loop position control system in normal operation or / and catalyst heating
System deviation outside the admissible range in normal operation or / and catalyst heating.

� 2. BPA actuator diagnosis - Calculate admissible control deviation
Procedure / Hints:
? The admissible control deviation is calculated by a characteristic line and the gradient of the requested
setpoint for position control. The corresponding gradient is determined with a low ?lter of ?rst order and
is the result between actual and ?ltered setpoint request. The ?lter correlation constant in?uences the
time behavior of the gradient.
?

gradient

pressure actuator setpoint gradient
� 3. BPA actuator diagnosis - Monitor of the position controller output
Procedure / Hints:
? This section calculates the moving mean value of the position controller output. If the battery voltage
falls below the de?ned threshold then the calculation is stopped and reset.
?

� 4. BPA actuator diagnosis - Error detection
Procedure / Hints:
The error detection algorithm checks the control deviation and the PWM mean value of the position control
system. If the valid range of the process values is violated then an error will be indicated.

� Adaptation and Diagnosis
The adaptation and diagnosis function is composed of two types of sensor adaptation:
- the active adaptation: for those situations where no previous valid values are stored (at end of production
line, loss of NVMY) the valve is moved to its top and bottom limits and these end position sensor values are
acquired and stored.
- the passive adaptation: during normal operation of the valve, it may reach its end positions. In such cases, an
opportunity is available to learn the end positions without interrupting the normal operation. Once the valve
is in the end position and is desired to be there, the passive adaptation will attempt to learn the end position
sensor value. If it is interrupted by a change of setpoint, it will stop the adaptation attempt.
When the actuator heats up during use, the end position sensor values can change as well. To compensate,
a temperature dependency can be learnt which interpolates the values of the four ranges (_0 to _3) of a
temperature scala. Use these C_TEMP_BPA_AD_THD_x to de?ne cold, normal, warm and hot ranges with their
own acquired end position sensor values. Initilization at key on is done with the default range _1, so this range
should contain ?room temperature? calibration. On a testbench the starting values for the end positions of this
range can be saved in C_VP_BPA_BOL/TOL_SUB. The testbench values of the other ranges can be saved in
C_VP_BPA_AD_BOL/TOL_OFS_SUB_RNG_0/_2/_3. These depend strongly on the position of the actuator and
sensor with respect to the engine and how much heat is absorbed by the actuator.

� Position Controller
This module describes the digital position controller used for the closed loop control. The position controller
is carried out as a digital robust position controller. Calibration data are determined according to internal
position controller design algorithms. The controller algorithm is split in 1 ms functionality for closed loop
position control and 10 ms functionality for static preload and battery voltage correction.
The transfer function of the position controller is used for the decoupling between static and dynamic behavior,
that means the static closed-loop ampli?cation has to be higher than the dynamic closed-loop ampli?cation.
The transfer function is described in the continuous range as PDT1 transfer function as follow:
Figure 9.24.2: PDT1 transfer function

� Safety Limitation
To protect the actuator, the maximum static PWM has to be limited.
In case of dynamic there is no protection limitation.
� 1. Safety Limitation - Temperature Initialization
? The difference between the coolant temperature at end of PWL and restart of ECU is used as a mea-
sure for the ECU off time. Assuming that a short ECU off time will lead to a small drop of the actuator
temperature, the temperatures are initialized with their old values at end of PWL. For a longer ECU time
the temperatures are approximated between ambient and coolant temperature, but with a delay time to
ensure a valid TAM value. During the delay time a substitute value is used.
? A substitute value (C_TEMP_SUB_BPA) is used for initialization of model temperatures.
Calibration label Calibration advice
C_TCE_DIF_MIN_BPA Minimum temperature difference between ECU off time, at which TEMP_BPA_PROT is take
from NVMY
C_TEMP_SUB_BPA Substitute temperature during initialization of model
C_CRLC_PWM_FIL_EGY_BPA Correlation constant for fast pwm ?ltering for summation at 10ms task
C_T_MAX_TCE_GRD_BPA Period width for TCE gradient calculation
C_T_ST_TEMP_MDL_BPA Delay time for disable of temperature calculation in case of longer ECU off time
IP_FAC_MDL_TCE_BPA Factor for cooling bpa actuator
� 2. Safety Limitation - Rotor Temperature and Calculation Electrical Energy
? The temperature is calculated via integration of the energy ?ow applied to the rotor. This energy is
separated into the electrical energy added to it and the thermal head ?ux to its ambient. For notes on
the calculation see at overall energy calculation for actuator case later in this document.
? The induced energy to the rotor is simpli?ed by calculation of the effective voltage multiplied by a factor
for the internal resistor of the dc motor.
? During initialization of the temperature model, TEMP_BPA_PROT is set to a substitute value to avoid
problems with the availability of TAM.

The protection limitation is based on the maximum static PWM.

� 4. Safety Limitation - Actuator Force Limitation
The actuator force must be limited to protect the waste gate. A temperature depending PWM value is used to
limit the mechanical power of the dc motor and corrected by several factors:
1. Caused by a preferred direction of the exhaust gas pressure, the force can be reduced in direction of the
upper limit.(IP_FAC_PWM_VP_BPA).
2. The effective electrical power is supply voltage dependent. (IP_FAC_PWM_VB_BPA).
3. Near the bottom limit, the force must be increased due to a higher exhaust gas pressure.
(IP_FAC_PWM_BPA_TOL_PQ_EX / IP_FAC_PWM_BPA_BOL_PQ_EX).

� Anti-Sticking Function
The antisticking function is activated when a control deviation persists while the actuator does not move. This
"stuck level" is expressed in a factor, which needs to rise above a minimal value before requesting permission
to control the actuator. If true, a setpoint is passed on to the valve in addition to the setpoint which was valid
at the moment of activating the antisticking. The used setpoint is an increasing pulse overlapping the original
setpoint.

� Cleaning-Function
The cleaning function repeatedly opens and closes the actuator across a large range in order to knock off
soot or deposits. It can take place in coasting phases and/or in ECU powerlatch phase after key off, where the
actuator is not used for airpath control. The setpoint signal during cleaning consists of a calibratable number
of repeated open / close cycles with calibratable output values.

well (1).

power latch state

Figure 9.25.22: Go to position for post operating phase
9.25.2.1.1.10 STATE Post Operating Phase
In case if ignition key off this state is activated.
If the counter for actuator operation CTR_BPA_OPM is lower than C_CTR_BPA_OPM threshold and the ECU
operating state is power latch not determined by wake-up (LV_BPA_CTL_PWL_ACT_ENA = 1), the boost pressure
actuator runs through intermediary engine stop operation where closed-loop or open-loop actuator control is
still possible.
If the actuator operation counter CTR_BPA_OPM exceeds C_CTR_BPA_OPM threshold or the ECU enters de-
activation or wake-up state or the power latch state comes after wake-up (LV_BPA_CTL_PWL_ACT_ENA = 0),
the boost pressure actuator control should be de-activated (STATE_BPA_CTL = PWM_OFF).
The ECU operation in power latch: only from ECU MAIN operating state or power latch available after wake-up
can be de-activated by setting LC_BPA_CTL_PWL_WKU_ACT = 1.
If the ignition is off but the engine is still running, the ECU state SYN_OFF (engine synchronous, ignition off)
will be activated. In this state, closed loop actuator control should be possible in order to bring the wastegate
to the position required in post operating phase, otherwise the exhaust gas pressure will press on the waste-
gate trying to keep it open and this may cause un-wanted rattling noise. It is only possible to activate closed
loop position control during SYN_OFF state when LC_BPA_CTL_SYN_OFF_ACT is set.

Figure 9.25.25: PWM limitation
9.25.2.1.1.12 Overview Calculation of condition for static PWM
In the bottom and top limit the actuator is working with a static PWM, without position controller.
The conditions for static mode - wastegate in BOL or TOL positions - are setpoint and actual value are inside a
range.
In noise mode, the wastegate has to be closed in order to avoid oscillations which could produce a ringing
sound. LV_POSN_SP_BPA_RGL_NOISE = 1 represents the main condition for entering noise state; an additional
check is made in order to verify that the wastegate position follows the setpoint within a calibratable time (no
oscillations produced). For faster boost pressure build-up, the PWM value calculated for noise mode can be
switched to the static PWM value for bottom limit, depending on the accelerator pedal activation ratio.

CHRA, Boost pressure actuator operating manager
9.25.2.1.1.13 Calculation of Booster Variables for OBDC due to SAE J1979 / MY2011
STATE_BPA_SAE: OBDC Mode $01 Pid $70 - "Boost Pressure Control Status"
POSN_SP_BPA_SAE: OBDC Mode $01 Pid $72 - "Commanded Wastegate A/B Position supported"
STATE_BPA_SAE
set bit 0 =1 in case of STATE_BPA[0] means "Open Loop (no fault present)"
set bit 1 =1 in case of STATE_BPA[0] means "Closed Loop (no fault present)"
set bit 0 and bit 1 =1 in case of STATE_BPA[0] means "Fault present (boost data unreliable)"
set bit 2 =1 in case of STATE_BPA[1] means "Open Loop (no fault present)"
set bit 3 =1 in case of STATE_BPA[1] means "Closed Loop (no fault present)"
set bit 2 and bit 3 =1 in case of STATE_BPA[1] means "Fault present (boost data unreliable)"
Data type conversion for POSN_SP_BPA_SAE = POSN_SP_BPA is performed
Because the SCAN-Tool expects POSN_SP_BPA_SAE de?ned as U8 with the range of 0...100 %
a data type conversion is necessary.
POSN_SP_BPA is de?ned as S16 with -200...199.9 %.
Therefore...
POSN_BPA - ->POSN_BPA_SAE
-200...0 % - - > 0 %
0...100 % - - > 0...100%
100...199.9 % - - > 100%

� General Information
This module describes the digital position controller used for the closed loop control. The position controller
is carried out as a digital robust position controller. Calibration data are determined according to internal
position controller design algorithms. The controller algorithm is split in 1 ms functionality for closed loop
position control and 10 ms functionality for static preload and battery voltage correction.

Initialisation: RST, Deactivation
Activation: LC_BPA_CTL_ENA==1
Deactivation: LC_BPA_CTL_ENA==0
Recurrence: 1MS, 10MS

9.26.2.1.1.1.1.1 Digital Position Controller
The position controller is carried out as a robust digital position controller. Calibration data are determined
according to internal controller design. The position controller consists of a transfer function for the decou-
pling between static and dynamic behavior and adaptive controller ampli?cation in forward direction and an
additional phase correction in backward direction to in?uence the system damping.
To avoid additional delay between AD conversion and calculation it is necessary that the routines for calcula-
tion of POSN_BPA and PWM_BPA are called directly after the AD conversion is ?nished. The PMW output starts
immediately after its calculation. Calibration data are determined according to internal position controller de-
sign algorithms

Figure 9.27.7: Temperature Initialization
9.27.1.3.2.1.1 Temperature Initialization
The difference between the coolant temperature at end of PWL and restart of ECU is used as a measure for
the ECU off time. Assuming that a short ECU off time will lead to a small drop of the actuator temperature, the
temperatures are initialized with their old values at end of PWL. For a longer ECU time the temperatures are
approximated between ambient and coolant temperature, but with a delay time to ensure a valid TAM value.
During the delay time a substitute value is used.

9.27.3.1.1.1 Rotor Temperature Calculation
The temperature is calculated via integration of the energy ?ow applied to the rotor. This energy is sepa-
rated into the electrical energy added to it and the thermal head ?ux to its ambient. For notes on the calculation
see at overall energy calculation for actuator case later in this document.
During initialization of the temperature model, TEMP_BPA_PROT is set to a substitute value to avoid problems
with the availability of TAM.

Figure 9.27.19: Protection Limitation
9.27.3.1.1.3 Actuator Force Limitation
The actuator force must be limited to protect the waste gate.
In low loads, the wastegate can be closed with a lower force value (PWM_BPA_BOL_STAT_L) in order to avoid
wastegate noise. In case the ratio between the pressure setpoint at the intake manifold and the basic boost
pressure exceeds a threshold (given by a hysteresis to avoid pressure quotient toggling), it means the engine is
File: 7EW03D02.00P
2328Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

CHRA, Boost pressure actuator safety limitation
operating in a higher load area and the actuator should use a higher PWM value to keep the wastegate closed
in order to create boost.
In high loads, a temperature depending PWM value is used to limit the mechanical power of the dc motor and
corrected by several factors:
1. Caused by a preferred direction of the exhaust gas pressure, the force can be reduced in direction of the
upper limit. (IP_FAC_PWM_VP_BPA)
2. The effective electrical power is supply voltage dependent. (IP_FAC_PWM_VB_BPA)
3. Near the bottom limit, the force must be increased due to a higher exhaust gas pressure. (IP_FAC_PWM_
BPA_TOL_PQ_EX / IP_FAC_PWM_BPA_BOL_PQ_EX)
During pre-charging (when the turbocharger optimum response mode is active), the PWM value used for
keeping the wastegate closed can be limited by a threshold that depends on the exhaust gas pressure ra-
tio (exhaust gas pressure downstream the turbine divided by the exhaust pressure: PRS_EX_PCAT_UP / PRS_
EX). This is done so that there is no risk of damaging the wastegate by keeping it closed with a high PWM
value the whole pre-charge time.

9.27.4.1.3.3 Energy Flow and Integration Actuator Case
The case temperature is calculated via integration of the overall energy ?ux applied to the actuator. The head
is separated into:
- electrical energy origins from rotor and
- thermal in?uence from coolant water, turbine and ambient.
The in?uence from the ambient temperature depends on the vehicles speed and is represented as a curve of
the thermal resistance.
The temperature is calculated via integration over the energy ?ow. The used integration factor C_FAC_MEM_
TEMP_CASE_BPA is calculated as shown as k:
Figure 9.27.32: proportional factor for temperature integration

9.29.2.2.1.1 Sensor determination
In this subsystem, the boost pressure actuator position is determined depending on the actual voltage value
and the sensor slope.
The minimum voltage value over all driving cycles is calculated and saved in the non volatile memory at power
latch (used for component testing and calibration purpose, information about how far the wastegate opens).

� General Information
The antisticking function is activated when a control deviation persists while the actuator does not move. This
"stuck level" is expressed in a factor, which needs to rise above a minimal value before requesting permission
to control the actuator.
If true, a setpoint is passed on to the valve in addition to the setpoint which was valid at the moment of
activating the antisticking. The used setpoint is an increasing pulse overlapping the original setpoint.

9.30.2.1.1.1 Detection of stuck actuator
A request from antisticking module for boost pressure actuator will be sent whether all the next conditions are
ful?lled:
- the "stuck level" is equal or bigger than C_FAC_ACT_BPA_ANST,
- the actuator controller is active,
- the operating state is different than PROT and
- the antisticking active time is smaller than C_T_BPA_ANST_ACT_MAX.

Selection of activation conditions for boost pressure actuator cleaning
� General Information
The cleaning function repeatedly opens and closes the actuator across a large range in order to knock off
soot or deposits. It can take place in coasting phases and/or in ECU powerlatch phase after key off, where the
actuator is not used for airpath control.
The setpoint signal during cleaning consists of a calibratable number of repeated open/ close cycles with
calibratable output values.

9.32.1 Zielsetzung
� General Information
(English summary - rest of the speci?cation is in German)
The E-wastegate actuator (eWG) can, when given a too high control command, apply such a high force at the
end positions that the actuator and the turbo charger can get damaged. That?s why the actuator should not
apply any force higher than a de?ned maximal value at the end positions.
The different samples of the actuator at end of line have different DC-motor tolerances and reach therefore
under the same control command different forces. Because of this the de?ned maximal force should include
a buffer in order to take into account the dispersion between the different samples.
The aim of this function is to learn the deviation of the DC-motor of the current sample compared to a norm.
This way in future regulations close to the end positions a precise force de?nition will be possible. Moreover,
the buffer to the maximal possible force due to the dispersion between the different samples can be decreased
as much as possible.

## Function
This Simulink diagram represents a model for calculating the wastegate actuator pressure (PRS_WG_ACR). The primary function is to determine the appropriate pressure required to control the wastegate, likely within a turbocharged engine management system. The calculation takes into account various factors related to PWM signals, pressure sensors, and calibration data.

## Inputs
The diagram's key inputs include:

*   **PWM_WG:** Pulse Width Modulation signal, likely related to the desired or actual wastegate opening.
*   **PWM_VB_OFS_EPC_WG, FAC_PWM_VB_EPC_WG, PWM_WG_COR_OFS, PWM_WG_COR_SLOP:** Calibration data or offset values associated with the PWM signal.
*   **PRS_WG_ACR_EPC_L:** Low-side pressure sensor signal.
*   **PRS_WG_ACR_EPC_H:** High-side pressure sensor signal.
*   **PQ_EPC_IN:** Input related to pressure.
*   **PRS_WG_ACR_old:** Previous/Old Wastegate Actuator Pressure value
*   **C_CRLC_PRS_WG_ACR:** Calibration factor

## Outputs
The primary output of the system is:

*   **PRS_WG_ACR:** The calculated wastegate actuator pressure.

## Logic Flow
Here's a step-by-step breakdown of the logical flow:

1.  **PWM Signal Processing:** The PWM\_WG signal is adjusted using calibration parameters. PWM\_VB\_OFS\_EPC\_WG, FAC\_PWM\_VB\_EPC\_WG, PWM\_WG\_COR\_OFS, and PWM\_WG\_COR\_SLOP are used to correct the PWM signal (PWM\_WG).  The offsets are likely calculated based on the PWM signal.
2.  **PWM Correction Factor:** A correction factor for the PWM signal (PWM\_WG\_COR\_WG\_ACR) is calculated, which is potentially limited between 0 and 1.
3.  **Pressure Sensing:** Signals from high (PRS\_WG\_ACR\_EPC\_H) and low (PRS\_WG\_ACR\_EPC\_L) pressure sensors are used in conjunction with calibration parameters and PQ\_EPC\_IN input to calculate PQ\_EPC\_OUT, an intermediate pressure value.
4. **IP_PQ_EPC_OUT** This block takes x_val = PQ_EPC_OUT, and y_val = PQ_EPC_IN as input and based on the lookup table creates an output.
5.  **Actuator Pressure Calculation:**
    *   PQ\_EPC\_OUT and C\_CRLC\_PRS\_WG\_ACR are used in an addition and multiplication to calculate the new wastegate actuator pressure.
    *   PRS\_WG\_ACR\_old and C\_CRLC\_PRS\_WG\_ACR are used in an addition and multiplication to create new wastergate actuator pressure.
6.  **Control Signal Override:** PRS\_WG\_ACR\_NOT\_CTL influences the final actuator pressure (PRS\_WG\_ACR).

*   PRS\_WG\_ACR\_old and C\_CRLC\_PRS\_WG\_ACR are used in an addition and multiplication to create new wastergate actuator pressure.
6.  **Control Signal Override:** PRS\_WG\_ACR\_NOT\_CTL influences the final actuator pressure (PRS\_WG\_ACR).  If it's not active, a pressure value is chosen via the lookup table. Otherwise, one of the calculated pressure signals is chosen.

In summary, this model calculates the wastegate actuator pressure by considering PWM signal characteristics, pressure sensor readings, and calibration data. It's likely a critical part of a closed-loop control system designed to accurately regulate boost pressure in a turbocharged engine.

## Inputs

*   **LV\_CDN\_DIAG:** This appears to be a primary input signal indicating that the overall diagnostic condition evaluation is to be performed. It is likely a boolean signal that is TRUE (or 1) to indicate the condition is active.
*   **cdn\_diag\_out:** This signal appears to be used for extracting individual bits from a larger diagnostic output. It is an input to the `num_dec GET BIT` blocks. The value of this input is used to determine whether wastegate SCP, SCG, or OC should be diagnosed.

It is likely a boolean signal that is TRUE (or 1) to indicate the condition is active.
*   **cdn\_diag\_out:** This signal appears to be used for extracting individual bits from a larger diagnostic output. It is an input to the `num_dec GET BIT` blocks. The value of this input is used to determine whether wastegate SCP, SCG, or OC should be diagnosed.

## Outputs

*   **LV\_CDN\_DIAG\_WG\_SCP:** A boolean signal that is TRUE if the conditions are met for diagnosing the Waste Gate SCP (Short Circuit to Power) fault.
*   **LV\_CDN\_DIAG\_WG\_SCG:** A boolean signal that is TRUE if the conditions are met for diagnosing the Waste Gate SCG (Short Circuit to Ground) fault.
*   **LV\_CDN\_DIAG\_WG\_OC:** A boolean signal that is TRUE if the conditions are met for diagnosing the Waste Gate OC (Open Circuit) fault.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Bit Extraction:** The `cdn_diag_out` signal, along with index and base values, is fed to three `num_dec GET BIT` blocks. Each block extracts a single bit from the `cdn_diag_out` input. The "bit_sel" parameter within each block specifies which bit to extract:
    *   `bit_sel = 0` extracts the bit related to Waste Gate SCP.
    *   `bit_sel = 1` extracts the bit related to Waste Gate SCG.
    *   `bit_sel = 2` extracts the bit related to Waste Gate OC.

2.  **AND Logic:** The output of each `num_dec GET BIT` block and the `LV_CDN_DIAG` signal are fed into an AND logic gate. This means that the wastegate diagnostic condition is only met if *both* `LV_CDN_DIAG` is TRUE and the corresponding extracted bit from `cdn_diag_out` is TRUE.

3.  **Output Signals:** The outputs of the AND gates are the final condition signals:
    *   `LV_CDN_DIAG_WG_SCP` is TRUE only if `LV_CDN_DIAG` is TRUE *and* the Waste Gate SCP condition bit from `cdn_diag_out` is TRUE.
    *   `LV_CDN_DIAG_WG_SCG` is TRUE only if `LV_CDN_DIAG` is TRUE *and* the Waste Gate SCG condition bit from `cdn_diag_out` is TRUE.
    *   `LV_CDN_DIAG_WG_OC` is TRUE only if `LV_CDN_DIAG` is TRUE *and* the Waste Gate OC condition bit from `cdn_diag_out` is TRUE.

## Function

These state machines likely control the adaptation and diagnosis logic of the CHRA (Charge Air Housing Regulator Assembly) within a vehicle's engine management system. The purpose of the state machines is to manage the transition between different operating modes for adapting certain parameters, and to handle waiting periods.

## Inputs

    *   `STATE_BPA_AD_MNG_i`: State of BPA management.
    *   `LV_BPA_AD_REQ_i`: BPA request.
    *   `T_VP_BPA_AD_i`: BPA timeout.
    *   `LV_BPA_AD_ACT_CMD_i`: Actual command.
    *   `STATE_BPA_CTL_AD_i`: State of BPA Control.
    *   `POSN_SP_BPA_AD_i`: BPA position setpoint.
    *   `LV_BPA_AD_PAS_REQ_i`: BPA passive request.
    *   `STATE_BPA_CTL_AD_i`: State of BPA control
    *   `PWM_BPA_STAT_AD_i`: PWM BPA status

**State `WAIT`:**

*   `wait`: A bus signal containing:
    *   `STATE_BPA_AD_MNG_i`: State of BPA management.

## Logic Flow

**State `ST_ADAPT`:**

1.  The state machine receives input signals, including reset commands, position setpoints, requests for specific operating modes, and initialization values for the PWM.
2.  The `if` block checks the value of `<LV_BPA_AD_RST_ACT_CMD_i>`.
    *   If `<LV_BPA_AD_RST_ACT_CMD_i>` evaluates to true(1), outputs for WAIT state are assigned as following: `STATE_BPA_AD_MNG_i` is set to 1, `LV_BPA_AD_REQ_i` is set to 1, and `T_VP_BPA_AD_i` is set to 0.
    *   If `<LV_BPA_AD_RST_ACT_CMD_i>` evaluates to false(0), outputs for PWM_CTL state are assigned to 1 and the following signals are assigned: `LV_BPA_AD_ACT_CMD_i`, `STATE_BPA_CTL_AD_i` and `POSN_SP_BPA_AD_i`.
3.  The block `PWM_STAT` checks whether the inputs `C_PWM_INI_AD_BOL_BPA` and `C_PWM_INI_AD_BPA` are equal to 0. If the inputs are non-zero, then the following outputs from this state are set: `LV_BPA_AD_PAS_REQ_i`, `STATE_BPA_CTL_AD_i`, and `PWM_BPA_STAT_AD_i`.
4.  The outputs of the WAIT, PWM_CTL, and PWM_STAT states are merged into a single bus signal `ctl_tol`.

**State `WAIT`:**

1.  The state machine receives input signals `<LV_INH_BPA_AD>` and `<LV_BPA_AD_RST_ACT_CMD_i>`.
2.  The `AND` block combines both signals.
3.  The output of the `AND` block controls the input to `if` block which checks the result of `AND` operation.
    *   If the `AND` operation is true, the output of `INH` block is passed to the output, `STATE_BPA_AD_MNG_i`.
    *   Else if `AND` operation is false, the output of the `else` operator is passed to the output, `STATE_BPA_AD_MNG_i`. The output of `else` block is a constant `+1.00000e+001`
4.  The output from `INH` is merged using `BusMerge` block to create the `wait` output bus.

*   Else if `AND` operation is false, the output of the `else` operator is passed to the output, `STATE_BPA_AD_MNG_i`. The output of `else` block is a constant `+1.00000e+001`
4.  The output from `INH` is merged using `BusMerge` block to create the `wait` output bus.

In summary, the Simulink diagram defines two state machines that manage the adaptation and diagnosis of the CHRA system by handling reset commands, setting position setpoints, and transitioning between different operating states based on input signals.

## Function

The Simulink diagram calculates the diagnostic state in the case of no error symptom. It determines whether a diagnostic parameter is within its acceptable range based on comparing a current value with a maximum and a previous value. If within acceptable parameters it passes diagnostic checks and sets `PRM_STATE_FIL` to 1. If not it executes the else state and no operation is done.

## Inputs

*   `<ABC_BPA_DR_SC_MAX_i>`: Current value of the diagnostic parameter.
*   `C_ABC_MAX_BPA_DR`: Correction value applied to the current diagnostic parameter.
*   `ABC_BPA_DR_SC_MAX_i_old`: Previous value of the diagnostic parameter.

## Outputs

*   `PRM_STATE_FIL`: Diagnostic state filter. The value is set to 1 if the diagnostic parameter passes the checks.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Input Values:** The diagram receives the current diagnostic parameter value `<ABC_BPA_DR_SC_MAX_i>`, a correction value `C_ABC_MAX_BPA_DR`, and the previous value of the diagnostic parameter `ABC_BPA_DR_SC_MAX_i_old`.

2.  **Correction:** The current diagnostic parameter value is corrected by adding the `C_ABC_MAX_BPA_DR` value via a "+/-" block.

3.  **Maximum Value:** The corrected parameter value and the old value pass into a Max Block, which outputs the largest of the two.

4.  **Inequality Check:** The largest value from the maximum check and the original previous value are fed into an "Unequal" Block.  If they are unequal, the output is TRUE (1); otherwise, the output is FALSE (0).

5.  **AND Logic:** The value from the Inequality Check and the previous value are passed to an AND Block.

6. **Pass or No Event:** If the AND block is passed it output a PASS signal which sets the PRM_STATE_FIL signal to 1. If the AND block does not pass it outputs NO_EVE which executes the else function, which is not visualized in this diagram.

7. **Output:** The output PRM_STATE_FIL is passed and can be read from elsewhere in the Simulink Model.

## Function

The diagrams describe a diagnostic system for a sensor supply voltage (VP_BPA). It includes evaluation of the diagnostic condition, management of diagnostics, and symptom evaluation. Specifically, it covers:

*   **Evaluation of diagnostic condition:** Determining if a diagnostic should be triggered.
*   **Manage diagnostics:**  Deciding whether to execute the diagnostic routine based on the evaluated conditions.
*   **Symptom evaluation:** Comparing the sensor supply voltage to predefined maximum and minimum thresholds to determine symptom levels (high and low).

## Inputs

*   `<LV_INH_ERR_VP_BPA_i>`:  Inhibition error of VP_BPA.
*   `<LV_IGK>`:  An unspecified input, likely related to ignition or general system state.
*   `<LV_CDN_DIAG_VP_BPA_H_i>`:  Previously calculated diagnostic condition (high) for VP_BPA.
*   `<LV_CDN_DIAG_VP_BPA_L_i>`: Previously calculated diagnostic condition (low) for VP_BPA.
*   `<input_errm>`: Input error management variable.
*   `<VP_BPA_i>`: Sensor supply voltage.
*   `C_VP_BPA_MAX`: Maximum threshold for VP_BPA.
*   `C_VP_BPA_MIN`: Minimum threshold for VP_BPA.

## Outputs

*   `<LV_CDN_DIAG_VP_BPA_H_i>`:  Diagnostic condition (high) for VP_BPA.
*   `<LV_CDN_DIAG_VP_BPA_L_i>`:  Diagnostic condition (low) for VP_BPA.
*   `mng_err`:  Managed error output, representing the state of the error.
*   `<LV_SYM_VP_BPA_H_i>`:  Symptom level (high) for VP_BPA.
*   `<LV_SYM_VP_BPA_L_i>`:  Symptom level (low) for VP_BPA.

## Logic Flow

**1. Evaluation of diagnostic condition:**

*   `<LV_INH_ERR_VP_BPA_i>` is negated using a NOT gate.
*   The negated `<LV_INH_ERR_VP_BPA_i>` and `<LV_IGK>` are fed into an AND gate.
*   The output of the AND gate is assigned to both `<LV_CDN_DIAG_VP_BPA_H_i>` and `<LV_CDN_DIAG_VP_BPA_L_i>`. Thus the diagnostic condition high and low outputs are equal.

**2.

*   The negated `<LV_INH_ERR_VP_BPA_i>` and `<LV_IGK>` are fed into an AND gate.
*   The output of the AND gate is assigned to both `<LV_CDN_DIAG_VP_BPA_H_i>` and `<LV_CDN_DIAG_VP_BPA_L_i>`. Thus the diagnostic condition high and low outputs are equal.

**2. Manage diagnostics:**

*   `<LV_CDN_DIAG_VP_BPA_H_i>` and `<LV_CDN_DIAG_VP_BPA_L_i>` are inputs to an OR gate.
*   The output of the OR gate acts as the condition (`u1`) for an "if" block.
*   If `u1` is true (at least one of the diagnostic conditions is true), `<input_errm>` is passed through to the `CDN` block (X.2.1.1.2.1). If `u1` is false, `<input_errm>` is passed through to the `NOT_CDN` block (X.2.1.1.2.2).
*   The `CDN` and `NOT_CDN` block's outputs are merged using the `BusMerge` block to create the managed error output `mng_err`.

**3. Symptom Evaluation:**

*   `<VP_BPA_i>` is compared to `C_VP_BPA_MAX` using a "greater than" comparison.  If `<VP_BPA_i>` is greater than `C_VP_BPA_MAX`, `<LV_SYM_VP_BPA_H_i>` is set high.
*   `<VP_BPA_i>` is compared to `C_VP_BPA_MIN` using a "less than" comparison. If `<VP_BPA_i>` is less than `C_VP_BPA_MIN`, `<LV_SYM_VP_BPA_L_i>` is set high.

**4. Symptom Debouncing:**
* The description notes that "The standard ERRM API for the de-bouncing is used." Implying the outputs from Symptom Evaluation are processed by the error management API, to prevent rapid transitions of symptoms.

3.  **State Management (STAT Block):**  The STAT block manages the internal state of the system.  It receives feedback from its output and uses the "stat" signal.
4.  **Operation Mode (OPM Block):** The OPM block determines the operating mode of the system based on its input and provides feedback.

6.  **Output Generation (V.6.3 Block):** The block generates diagnostic outputs and control actions based on the calculations and monitored signals.  These outputs are then used to control the actuator and report any errors or abnormal conditions.

The system operates in a closed loop, where the outputs of the Actuator Diagnostics (V.6.3 Block) influence the state management and operation mode for the next iteration, ensuring continuous monitoring and control. The main purpose is to ensure that the position deviation symptom is reliably detected without being affected by noise or transient deviations.

## Inputs

*   `<POSN_DIF_BPA_i>`: Position deviation value.

*   `<VP_BPA_DIF_H_ERR_i>`: Actuator movement error value (negative side).
*   `<C_VP_BPA_OFS_NEG_DIF_i>`: Negative offset for actuator movement error.
*   `<ACTION_ERRM_GetErr_T3>`: Action error signal trigger.
*   `<NC_IDX_ERR_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_i>`: Control deviation error presence
*   `LC_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_DC_HEAL`: Calibration switch status.
*   `<LV_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_ERR_SET_i>`:  Error Set flag.

*   `LV_SYM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_ACT_can_i`: Debounced position deviation symptom signal.
*   `<LV_SYM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_RST_out_i>`:  Reset output.
*   `<LV ERR_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_rise_st_i>`:  Error Rise state.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Position Deviation Check:** The absolute value of `<POSN_DIF_BPA_i>` is compared against `<POSN_DIF_BPA_ERR_MAX_i>` using a relational operator.  The output indicates whether the position deviation exceeds the maximum allowed error.

2.  **Actuator Movement Check:** `<VP_BPA_DIF_H_ERR_i>` is compared against `<C_VP_BPA_OFS_POS_DIF_i>` and `<VP_BPA_DIF_H_ERR_i>` is also compared against `<C_VP_BPA_OFS_NEG_DIF_i>`, both using Min/Max blocks and relational operators. These logic blocks determine the overall magnitude of actuator movement/activity and assess if the value exceeds a defined band.

3.  **Deviation/Movement OR:**  The results from the position deviation check and the actuator movement checks are combined using an OR logic gate. The output of this gate indicates whether either a significant position deviation or actuator movement has been detected.

4.

These logic blocks determine the overall magnitude of actuator movement/activity and assess if the value exceeds a defined band.

3.  **Deviation/Movement OR:**  The results from the position deviation check and the actuator movement checks are combined using an OR logic gate. The output of this gate indicates whether either a significant position deviation or actuator movement has been detected.

4.  **Intermediate Symptom Signal Generation:** The output of the OR gate is then passed to a filter block which produces `LV_SYM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_i` signal.

5. **Reset logic:** The signal `LV_SYM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_i` is passed to an OR gate together with error signal `<NC_IDX_ERR_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_i>`, producing `LV_SYM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_RST_i`.

6. **Flip-Flop (FF):**  The  `LV_SYM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_RST_i` signal is connected to both SET and RESET input of a flip-flop (FF) with inputs ACTION_ERRM_GetErr.
The Q and Q_in outputs are routed to the `LV_SYM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_RST_out_i` output.

7. **Delay/Hysteresis:**  The output of the FF `LV_SYM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_RST_out_i` is put in a delay block, which produces `<LV ERR_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_rise_st_i>`.

8.  **Activation Logic:**  The signals `LC_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_DC_HEAL` and `<LV_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_ERR_SET_i>` are used as conditions using an AND gate.

9.  **Final Debouncing:**  The intermediate symptom signal and the output of the AND logic gate are then combined. This logic determines if the debounced symptom `LV_SYM_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_ACT_can_i` should be active. If the calibration switch (`LC_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_DC_HEAL`) is NOT set OR if there is no control deviation error (`<LV_POSN_DIF_BPA_H_ERR_SET_i>`), the final debounced symptom signal will become active based on previously calculated criteria.
